required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Acute Effect of Massage and Exercise on Muscle Tenderness
clinical_study.official_title: Danish: Integreret Motion p√• Arbejdspladsen (IRMA) English: Implementation of Exercise at the Workplace

lead_sponsor.agency: National Research Centre for the Working Environment, Denmark

clinical_study.source: National Research Centre for the Working Environment, Denmark

brief_summary.textblock: Many people experience pain, tenderness and soreness of joint and muscles, both in sport and working life. Pain killers can provide acute relief of pain, but may not be a feasible solution for all people. Here the investigators examine the acute effect of massage and exercise on induced muscle tenderness (delayed onset muscular soreness).

primary_outcome.measure: Perceived tenderness of the trapezius muscle on a numerical rating scale of 0-10
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from before to after the acute intervention (average of 0, 10, 20 and 60 min after the intervention)
primary_outcome.description: Perceived tenderness where 0 is no tenderness and 10 is worst imaginable tenderness

primary_outcome.measure: Pressure pain threshold of the trapezius muscle
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from before to after the acute intervention (average of 0, 10, 20 and 60 min after the intervention)

arm_group.description: massage will be provided for 10 minutes at the left or right trapezius (randomized)
exercise (shoulder shrugs with elastic resistance) will be performed for 10 minutes at the left or right trapezius (randomized)

intervention.description: Exercise will be performed for 10 minutes at the left or right trapezius (randomized)
massage will be provided for 10 minutes at the left or right trapezius (randomized)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- working age adults
Exclusion Criteria:
- blood pressure above 160/100
- disease of the cervical spine

facility.name: National Research Centre for the Working Environment

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: National Research Centre for the Working Environment, Denmark
